courseDescription: This course introduces students to computer aided drafting, where methods are taught with a major emphasis on practical application using two-dimensional AutoCAD software in the computer lab.  This includes the basic principles of civil engineering drawings to include but not limited to: dimensioning, spot elevations, contours, plan and profile view, section views, details, scaling, measurements.  It will introduce students to site plan drawings, structural views, architectural views, as well as buried infrastructure plan and profiles.  Finally, it will be the basis for preparation of a working set of plans, for use in all follow-on CET courses.

Basic plane surveying measurements and computations, survey control systems, elementary digital mapping and simple curves, and building construction survey and stakeout. Field exercises using standard surveying instrumentation, traverse and leveling techniques, topographic mapping and curve layout.

Introduction to various materials and methods available for design and construction of buildings. Covers application and combination of traditional materials and methods, and recent innovations in construction systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Awareness of recent innovations in construction systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different material properties for construction

courseDescription: Standard Methods of inspecting and testing structural materials used in construction are demonstrated.  Data is collected and interpreted according to industry standards with results reported.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interpretation of test results according to industry standards
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members for testing procedures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of material properties based on test results

courseDescription: A detailed study of the form and content of typical construction drawings and 3D building models used in the construction industry. Commercial 3D CAD software is used to assemble a set of structural construction drawings.  Standard specification documents are introduced.

A detailed study into the development of civil site plans.  Commercial software (AutoCAD Civil 3D) is introduced as a tool to assist in the design of civil sites and develop a set of civil site drawings.
Study of selected topics.
Study of selected topics.

Introduction to structural design of buildings and/or nonbuilding type structures using reinforced concrete, steel, and wood as materials.  This course utilizes provisions of the American Concrete Institute ACI 318, American Institute of Steel construction AISC 360, and the National Design Specification NDS specifications. Forces, moments, and deflections in statically determinate beams, frames, and trusses due to various load cases and load combinations are determined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Structural design using reinforced concrete, steel, and wood
Utilization of ACI 318, AISC 360, and NDS specifications
Determining forces, moments, and deflections in beams, frames, and trusses
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of load cases and load combinations
Critical evaluation of structural design solutions

courseDescription: Applications of fundamental site engineering principles, land design principles and permitting issues. A brief historical review of exemplary subdivision, urban designs and their impact on current practice. Site surveying and engineering issues including hydrology, storm water management, site geometry, grading, design of roads, engineering design standards, and computer applications in site engineering are examined. The principles of siting and theories of design for aesthetic and efficient alignment of roads, layout of structures, and subdivision parcels are introduced.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Client interaction for project requirements gathering
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for site engineering tasks

courseDescription: Elementary mechanics of fluids.  Fluid properties; hydrostatics; fluid kinematics; equations of motion; energy equation; momentum principles; flow of liquids and gasses in closed conduits; flow in open channels and/or compressible flow.  Laboratory will demonstrate principles from the lecture material.  All experiment results will be submitted in a written report format, including presentation and interpretation of experimental data. Use of spreadsheets is required.

Hydrologic and Hydraulic principles are utilized in the planning, design, operation and construction of water management projects. The course addresses fundamental Hydrology - the occurrence and movement of surface water including weather and climate; precipitation; evaporation; transpiration; runoff; infiltration; stream flow; hydrograph analysis; erosion; and sedimentation.  Additional topics covered will include water distribution, use of water, and sustainability of water as a natural resource.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with multidisciplinary teams on water management projects
Clear presentation of hydrologic and hydraulic findings to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of hydrologic data for project planning
Problem-solving in water distribution system design
Analytical approach to sustainability assessment of water resources
Data-driven decision-making in water management projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in water resources engineering
Team coordination for successful implementation of water management projects

courseDescription: Application of computer software in solving water resources problems; program development or application of available packages to solve assigned water resources problems. Use and application of commercial software for analysis and design of water distribution networks and gravity sewer collection systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing commercial software for water distribution analysis
Developing programs for water resource problem solving
Applying available software packages for water resources problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in water resource problem solving

courseDescription: A laboratory to demonstrate the verification of fluid equations and principles as well as the characteristics of fluid machinery. All experimental results will be submitted in a report format, including presentation and interpretation of experimental data. Use of spreadsheets is required.  This is an online asynchronous class open only to transfer students with credit for the lecture portion of CET 330.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with team members for experiments

courseDescription: A study of the engineering properties of soil including stress, shear strength, and bearing capacity. Movement of water through soils, consolidation and settlement of structures and the design of shallow and deep foundations are also covered. Use of Excel spreadsheets is a requirement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in stress and shear strength analysis

courseDescription: Course includes standard methods for inspecting, sampling, testing, and evaluating soils. Students use typical test equipment and perform tests on samples of local soils. Data is collected and results are interpreted and plotted.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on soil testing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of soil properties from test results
Interpretation and analysis of soil data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating soil testing activities
Supervising and guiding team members in testing procedures

courseDescription: The course will examine industry trends in sustainable building practices. It explores the green building strategies used in the design and construction of sustainable buildings. The role of site selection, water efficiency, energy, materials and resources, and indoor environmental quality will be explored.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration in sustainable design projects
Clear communication of sustainable building concepts to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and solving sustainability challenges in building projects
Analyzing data for sustainable building decision-making
Implementing innovative solutions for sustainable practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading sustainability initiatives in building projects
Organizing resources for sustainable construction practices

courseDescription: An introduction to the procedures and methods that are used by a contractor during the construction phase of a project. Special emphasis on planning, managing and documenting project activities. Topics include job site layout and control, subcontracting and purchasing and changes and claims/progress payments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Project planning software proficiency (e.g., Microsoft Project)
Understanding job site layout and control techniques
Knowledge of subcontracting and purchasing processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation skills for changes and claims/progress payments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing project progress and identifying deviations from the plan
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing project timelines and resources efficiently
Providing leadership in handling changes and claims during construction projects

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to building information modeling (BIM) and its implementation in building design and construction. Topics include the fundamentals of information modeling; business benefits of BIM; impacts of BIM on design and construction processes; integrated design process and project delivery; popular software applications and basic modeling techniques; and popular areas and best practices of BIM implementation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Building Information Modeling software proficiency (e.g., Revit, AutoCAD)
Understanding of integrated design process and project delivery
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing impacts of BIM on design and construction processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a BIM context

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Management prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.  (offered fall, spring, summer)  (qualifies as a CAP experience)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of work experience outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of work experience tasks

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a professional setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a work environment

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hands-on experience with industry tools and technologies

courseDescription: Topics in Civil Engineering Technology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of technical concepts to non-engineers
Collaboration with architects and contractors on projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of structural design parameters
Problem identification and resolution in construction projects
Risk assessment and mitigation in civil engineering scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team leadership in construction site environments
Resource allocation and management in civil engineering projects

courseDescription: Topics in Civil Engineering Technology.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in designing civil engineering solutions

courseDescription: Analysis of indeterminate structures including the verification of results using the commercial software RISA 3D. Introduction to computer modeling in 2D and 3D, pre and post processors, interpretation of results and development of professionally written reports. Structural analysis topics include influence lines, cables and arches, slope deflection, moment distribution, and stiffness methods of analysis.  Analysis and design of structures using steel, wood, and reinforced concrete materials using RISA 3D.  Design meeting strength and serviceability requirements per codes, specifications, and standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design of structures in steel, wood, and reinforced concrete materials
Meeting strength and serviceability requirements per codes, specifications, and standards
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on structural projects
Presentation of analysis results to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of structural analysis outcomes
Understanding influence lines, cables, arches, slope deflection, moment distribution, and stiffness methods of analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for structural design tasks
Adherence to industry standards and regulations in design processes

courseDescription: Structural analysis and design of steel structures, including beams, girders, columns, composite sections, trusses, rigid frames and connections using the LRFD method. Analysis of statically-determinate cantilever (hungspan) systems also are covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design of steel beams, girders, columns, composite sections, trusses, rigid frames
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for steel structure assessment

courseDescription: Familiarize the student with the analysis of environmental design loads required for the design of building and non-building type structures in the United States.  A thorough study of loading categories and load combinations for ASD and LRFD is also covered.  Extensive use of the International Building Code (IBC) and the Minimum Design Loads for Building and Other Structures (ASCE 7) is expected.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with Minimum Design Loads for Building and Other Structures (ASCE 7)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of environmental design load requirements

courseDescription: Structural analysis and design of reinforced concrete members. Topics include flexural analysis and design of structures, including slabs, beams and columns using strength design procedures.
Analysis and design of wooden structural elements of buildings to satisfy design codes. Included are shearwall design and connections as well as beams, columns and other elements.
Technical and Digital Skills: Connection design for beams and columns

courseDescription: Familiarize the student with the analysis and design of simple and continuous span bridge structures utilizing the Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD) methodology. Determination of the most common design loads used in bridge design. Introduction to the AASHTO Specification for Structural Bridge Design used in United States.
Technical and Digital Skills: Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD) methodology
Analysis and design of bridge structures
Determination of design loads in bridge design
AASHTO Specification for Structural Bridge Design

courseDescription: Analysis and design of reinforced concrete foundations typically used in buildings and bridges. Topics include loads and loading groups, methods of analysis and design, abutments, and isolated and continuous footings. The class will be focused on the load and resistant factor design method. Use of the ASCE 7, ACI and AASTHO codes is necessary.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis and design of reinforced concrete foundations
ASCE 7, ACI, and AASTHO codes application
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Methods of analysis and design implementation

courseDescription: Hydrologic and hydraulic principles are utilized in the planning, design, operation and construction of water management projects. Topics include elements of stormwater drainage pertaining to hydrology, hydraulics of open channel and pipe flow, stormwater management, and issues pertinent to state stormwater regulations and the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Act.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with multidisciplinary teams for project planning and implementation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of drainage issues and solutions
Application of hydraulic principles in problem-solving
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and coordination for water management projects
Leadership in implementing stormwater management strategies

courseDescription: This is a capstone design course in the field of water resources.  It incorporates pressurized pipe flow, gravity flow, and hydrology into the design of municipal infrastructure for water, sewer and stormwater projects.  Topics will also cover rehabilitation and replacement of aging infrastructure in urban and neighborhood settings.  Use of spreadsheets is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with team members and stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of infrastructure design options
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in infrastructure planning and implementation

courseDescription: Analysis of hydraulics problems associated with the design of civil engineering structures. Uniform, steady flow in open channels; hydraulic models; design problems for dams; spillways and hydraulic structures; hydraulic machinery and other related topics will be discussed. Use of spreadsheets is required.

An investigation of emerging construction industry trends in resilience and sustainability.  Evaluation of applications for vulnerable, small-scale and rural projects. Quantify increases in project value by incorporating life cycle analysis, planning for continuity of function, and deliberate risk management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of construction industry trends in sustainability and resilience
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of project value increases
Collaboration with vulnerable, small-scale, and rural project stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Quantitative analysis of project value increases
Critical evaluation of resilience and sustainability applications in construction projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning for continuity of function in construction projects
Leadership in incorporating sustainability practices in project planning

courseDescription: This course provides a structured framework for developing resilience. It focuses on addressing the impacts of the climate crisis like flooding, heat, water, and wildfire through principles, designs, and real-world solutions. This is achieved by examining hard engineering structures, nature-based design, and hybrid solutions to protect communities and create a resilient design future.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing hybrid solutions for climate resilience
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with diverse stakeholders in climate crisis projects
Communicating complex climate impact data effectively to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data on climate crisis impacts like flooding, heat, water, and wildfire
Designing real-world solutions for resilient communities based on data insights
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing community engagement events for climate resilience initiatives

courseDescription: Evaluation and analysis of the basic elements of estimating construction costs for buildings.  Elements of take off and pricing for Division 1 through Division 6 are covered.  Use of computers and estimating software are emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Take off and pricing techniques for Division 1-6

courseDescription: The basic elements of planning and scheduling building construction projects.  All elements of building construction, including the precedence methods of scheduling.  Use of computers and planning and scheduling software are emphasized.

This course provides a study of financial management in civil engineering construction projects. It emphasizes the development of techniques for effective financial monitoring. Additionally, the curriculum covers concepts related to construction equipment utilization, ensuring an economic alignment of machine capabilities with project requirements. It also addresses the application of time value of money principles for financial decision-making in equipment selection and utilization for heavy highway and major building construction projects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Time value of money principles application
Equipment utilization alignment with project requirements

courseDescription: The basic concepts of contracts and the standard contract documents used in construction. Also included is a study of the dispute resolution process in arbitration.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of standard contract documents in construction
Familiarity with legal aspects of contracts in arbitration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing contract clauses for potential conflicts
Evaluating legal implications of contract language
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating dispute resolution procedures in arbitration

courseDescription: Topics in civil engineering technology.
Technical and Digital Skills: AutoCAD skills for drafting and design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration on project implementation
Clear and concise technical report writing
Oral presentation skills for project proposals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in assessing engineering challenges
Root cause analysis for structural failures
Data interpretation and analysis for design optimization
Innovative solutions for sustainability in construction projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Resource allocation and scheduling for project timelines

courseDescription: Topics in civil engineering technology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of engineering concepts to non-technical stakeholders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in civil engineering projects
Team coordination for construction site operations
